Mount for a inductive proximity sensor on a stock Sunhokey Prusa i3 2015

Mounting

The part is intended to be mounted on the left of the X-carriage, wedged in between the left tension clip screw. You may need to thread or re-drill the 3mm mounting hole, if it's too tight.

To mount the part, I removed the fan and unscrewed the left tension clip screw. The part was inserted in between the metal tension clip and the acrylic plate and all 3 screwed tight using a 3mm screw and nut. The sensor can be adjusted for height during calibration.

title: Wine Bottle Dryer Rack Dowel V3
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
2/26/2017 UPDATE: I have now included the Bottle Drying Tree Body in two different versions. One with 1/4 inch holes AND the other with 3/8 inch holes for heavier bottles. They are labeled accordingly. The 1/4 inch dowels flex more with heavier bottles, so if this makes you nervous, then simply use the 3/8 dowel version! Download whichever you would like to use. Depending on the accuracy of your machine, you may have to sand the ends of the dowels a little to get them to fit. ALSO, I recommend scaling down the legs to 99% in your slicer to allow them to be inserted into the base a little easier. My original tolerances were a little too tight. You can still print them at full size, you will just have to sand them a little.

So, I have been an amateur Vintner (Wine Maker) for about 3 years, now, and I really enjoy it. However, all the bottle drying racks I have seen aren't exactly what I want. I found this one by buzzsaw2222, but it was designed for smaller beer bottles, and risked breaking the arms if I placed heavier wine bottles on them. I certainly don't want that.

So you can say I was inspired by the design, but I completely tore it down and redesigned it. Mine has a 6 wine bottle capacity for each Body segment you print. Bottles are held up by 1/4 inch wood dowels you can cut to your own length (6 inches works well) and insert into the holes in the Body. It also offers drainage that directs the sanitizing solution draining off the bottles to one of the legs. This allows you to place it beside a sink and have the drainage go into the sink rather than onto the countertop. I also had issues with flatness on the bottom of the legs, so I added ball feet to allow it to sit more securely on slightly uneven surfaces. To install these, simply turn the legs over and tap the feet into each hole until they stop. Assemble, and test for flatness on the countertop.

I laid out the initial Complete Kit to fit on a 200mm X 200mm print bed. I am including the parts separately, as well, so you can print them however you want. If you decide to print them separately you will need:
1) Bottle Drying Tree Draining Base
1) Bottle Drying Tree Body (or more of these to increase capacity)
1) Bottle Drying Tree Draining Leg
3) Bottle Drying Tree Legs
8) Bottle Drying Tree Feet

All in all, I am pretty happy with it. If you want to dry more bottles, print more Body segments and build the tree higher. I recommend no more than 4 Body segments high for stability. Also, be sure to EVENLY space your bottles across from each if you aren't completely filling up one of the Body segments. That way you don't get the "Leaning Tower of Pisa" effect and risk the tree falling over, or becoming unstable. You don't want to break those precious wine bottles you worked so hard for, or cut yourself on broken glass! Four segments will yield 24 bottles which is about a 5 gallon batch of wine ( and a couple glasses left over for your own tasting! :-)
ENJOY!

Printer:

ANet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.15

Infill:

30

comments.author: Mattao

comments.text: Thanks!  Hopefully it works as well for you as it has for me!
comments.author: Mattao

comments.text: Just wondering what kind of control do you have since your not using a gopro? The gimble still rotates as it should? Does the hdmi charge your camera? Any video drop outs on your display?
comments.author: olevelo

comments.text: There's no control of the camera, just the live video feed.  I just start recording right before powering up the motors (I have quick record enabled, so it's just a single button press on the camera), and then stop it after landing.  The gimbal works as it's supposed to (note that it only rotates up and down, as side to side rotation is done by yawing the entire aircraft...but the gimbal still moves slightly in all axes to stabilize the picture).  The HDMI does not charge the camera.  But it's not really an issue...remember you only get 15-20 minutes of flight time on each battery.  So unless you're flying 4-5 batteries in a row, you shouldn't run out of camera battery either.  No drop outs in the video.
comments.author: Mattao

comments.text: Really helpful thanks for the info, it can be so hard to hunt down facts on stuff like that.

title: Duplo compatible mushroom
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This fall we have seen lots of different mushrooms almost anywhere we went. After a quick search we learned that this is another custom piece that will need to be designed and printed to work with our Duplo toys.

The toy is built from two pieces, the "stem" and the "hat".

STEM
Stem consist of two cylinders subtracted from one another that creates a "pipe". This controls the wall thickness. Than a small platform is printed on top and than this process is repeated with a smaller diameter tube. This servers as knob where the "hat" locks in. The stem itself lock onto a regular Duplo block.

HAT
Hat is the top part of the mushroom and lock on top of the "stem".

Other projects:
Terracotta roof blocks: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1428521
Adjustable Roof hinges: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1440521

How the stem and hat are designed.

Stem
Stem consist of two cylinders subtracted from one another that creates a "pipe". This controls the wall thickness. Than a small platform is printed on top and than this process is repeated with a smaller diameter tube. This servers as knob where the "hat" locks in.

All the parameters can be changed to optimize for your printer or for a different project.

Hat
The "hat" is created by sphere being cut in half by subtracting a cube from it. Further a cylinder is subtracted from the bottom flat part of the hat creating a cavity where the "stem" locks in.
We created two kinds if mushrooms, ones that are rather cylindrical (muchotravka_Public_EB.scad) and the a more flatter hat (bedla_Public_ebreuer.scad). In order for the flatter sphere creation you may need to update your OpenScad to a never version, which I had to. (works on OpenSCAD version 2015.03-1 version)


The resize here does the trick:

resize ([0,0,10])
sphere(r=hat_radius);

Various stems Determining stem heigh to scale When printed upside down (left) the hat will flatten on top The flatter kind of mushroom (bedla) on left; Right: a cylindrical mushroom (muchotravka) Hat being printed upside down -- not recommended

description.text:
Add new file for part 3 to made it stronger, now V2_3 ( old one seems to break with some people ) Part 3 needs to be print with 100% infill.
Add 2 new V2 files with improvement of the parts 1 and 2. (See last photo)
This new version makes the construction more rigid
If you use the new parts you will need a longer screw for the belt tension

This tensioner can be installed without any modification on the a8 and makes it easy to tighten the belt.
For mounting on the frame are four M3 x 18 screws and four M3 nuts needed. For the tension you need one M3 x 18 screw and 1 M3 locknut. And two more M3 x 20 with locknut to mount the bearings and the pivot point.
I used three M3 washers on the bearings, one between the bearings and the other two between the bearing and the frame.

Printer:

Anet A8

Resolution:

0,2

Infill:

50

Notes:

Wall 1.6

title: Anet A8 Bowden Extruder - The easy way
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is an all-in-one upgrade kit to get a bowden extruder for your anet a8. My target was to use as many parts as possible from the original kit, so most parts used for the upgrade are spare or original parts from the kit or parts you could print by yourself.

In addition you will need to M10 Push Fittings and some teflon tube which is available as a kit at Banggood:
http://www.banggood.com/1M-PTFE-Teflon-Bowden-Tube-For-Reprap-3D-Printer-1_75mm-Filament-p-1089552.html?p=5F23158121713201612L

The only other parts I added are some M3 and M4 nuts and washers.

Credits:
The mounting adapter was taken from 3Dator´s Bowden Extruder
The motor block was customized from Lancervo21´s Anet A8 Bowden update
All screw threads were generated with Poor man´s openscad screw library

Printer:

Anet A8

Resolution:

0.2

Notes:

Print the pneumatic_adapter with 100% infill as this has to be pretty solid. The other parts were printed at 50% but less may be good as well.

The adapter has to be rotated by 180° before printing.

Step 1

Print all the Parts and make sure the all holes have the correct size. You may need to use a drill to make them wider, especially the one the filament will pass through.

After that, attach the push-in Fittings as shown in the pictures below.

Step 2

Disassemble the extruder, you will have to take it completly apart for the conversion. After that, begin with the reassembly as shown in the pictures.

For attaching the fan to the hotend I left out the heatsink as I don´t see it´s purpose anymore. As a spacer between the fan and the aluminium block my Anet A8 extruder lamp could be used. This is not the perfect solution but it does the job. As an alternative you could also use some nuts as spacers.

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1883172

Make sure everything fits very tight Step 3

Now we will start to assemble the extruder Motor.

All needed parts How the mounting adapter is positioned Add an additional M4 nut to the screw as spacer assembly of the feeder block should look like this make sure the pinion gear is aligned correctly, put away the black part after that now attach the feeder block to the motor. I originally wanted to use fitting screws but I could not find any so I used two washers now attach the black part and mount the spring between both parts. Step 4

Congrats, you´re almost done.

As I could not find an appropriate spot to mount the motor on the printer frame, I mounted the whole printer on a piece of wood and put the motor next to it.

Now you just have to attach the teflon tube and connect the motor to the mainboard again.

You may have noticed that the color of the adapter changed during assembly. The reason is pretty simple, the gray part was printed with 50% infill like the other but broke at one point during assembly so I had to print it again.

$fn = 100

fingersize = 24
wobble = 1.5

This token is made for printing different filaments you have so you can remember what a print of that filament looks like and you can even write the optimal print settings on the back of the token. Honestly, I don't care what you to with the design, remix it, sell it, whatever. That is why I put it under the licence of CC Attribution, although you don't have to give attribution.

I used OpenSCAD to design this.

The file in OpenSCAD

this is to secure the z-axis after finishing the Print and also to have a good parking position while the printer is turned off

every thing beside the pin should be printed without support.

the goal was to make it fully printable - the screws that are needed are frome the spared screws that come with the printer - so you dont need anything else :)

the hook itself, i printed with full infill (maybe one setting lower would also work - but i just want to make sure its stabel :) )

the hammernuts should be printed with full infill - maybe you need to file them a bit to fitt better

the settings you see on the picture - the pin has to be rotated by 180° on the x or y axis.

the hoock_nut_position ist to help install the hammer nuts on the right position - the bar on top should rest on the z-axis top to get the right positions.

you should use vaseline on the shaft where the hook is insert in - also on the pin end

Printer:

Cetus3d Printer

Rafts:

Yes

title: FlexRC - Nail clipper propeller cutter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Use your favorite nail clipper to cut propellers for micro racing drone down to selected diameter in just a few seconds.

To simplify measurement this propeller cutter has marks for 2″-1.5″ diameters.

Don't own 3D printer? Not a problem, It can be purchased here:
https://flexrc.com/product/nail-clipper-propeller-cutter/

It works great for awesome RotorX RX2535 props:
https://flexrc.com/product/rotorx-rx2535w-props-8-cw-8-ccw/

and generates great results for FlexRC drones like:

  • Mini Owl: https://flexrc.com/product/mini-owl-frame/
  • Pico Owl: https://flexrc.com/product/pico-owl-v2-frame/
  • Pico X: https://flexrc.com/product/pico-x-frame/

and any other drones which require good micro propellers.

  • Please note that you can't resell or include this propeller cutter with your product without written permission from FlexRC

What is it: Bosch dishwasher lower rack wheel

Why: One of my wheels broke and the lower rack kept dropping, so I took it as an opportunity to begin to learn fusion 360 and simplify3D and the right combination of settings to replicate a nice part. It's a fairly small.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator Z18

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Addition Simplify3D print specs:

Layer: 3 shells
Additions: Raft offset- 3mm / Sep distance 0.17mm
Support: S infill 20% / Horizontal sep offset 0.4mm / Pillar S resolution 3mm
Temperature: Extruder 214C / Chamber 20C (it's cold in the garage)

First dimensional, functional part built in Fusion 360. Used Adobe Illustrator and calipers to spec Fusion sketches, brought screen grab as canvas and followed my dimensions. New to solid modeling and while there are $5 replacement parts available, I wanted to challenge myself to make something useful while learning Fusion. Purchased Simplify3D for more slicing control. Works great.

comments.text: The model is greatly improved over the original but it needs to be looked at the same way you would a marble statue the hair is too thin and probably should be projected out the back till it goes into the head as it has such a fine overlap in small scale the feathers just need increased thickness in the front at the shoulders as they don't really touch the armor more then a tiny fraction and then things should print a lot better. There are a few flipped faces in the model but that's to be expected of any video game model as the faces overlap each other forming closed objects and don't take into account issues that would arise from attempting to create them as real life objects or prints however the model as a whole should be fairly printable if someone was able to fix those problems. With my background not in organic modeling I'm no good in it just understanding it. I think you might also want to add a bit more connection with the body from the cloak or separate them into two different assets.

I agree. I´v tried to print this at least 7 times on 3 different printers, but it´s impossible. Everytime the feathers from the shoulders breaks away from the support, or they just mess up. No matter how much support or infill I have, It still hates me. :(

comments.text: Open it in MeshMixer any face that isn't Grey is flipped. You'll notice most of them are places that should be holes. Main issue is that the parts like the bow string the hair is just too thin to print think of a marble or clay statue if you couldn't carve it from the marble you won't be able to print it well. What faces you see as errors are just the tip of the iceberg, because it's a game model it is created with no concern for overlapping of armor and body so the best way would probably be to make it solid then sculpt.

description.text:
20170228 : Attention -- Possible issue when in a hot environment
I ran in a tolerance issue when printing ABS. The top part of the printer was around 50°C and the thermal expansion caused step skipping due to grinding between the stepper motor and the 2020-profile. I've added some extra room (2mm) between the stepper and the 2020-profile with a new front and back plate.
Unless you only print PLA, I strongly recommend to use files FrontV2.STL and BackV2.STL !!
Tested and works nicely now. See last picture for the added room between profile and stepper.

I made also a new TOPV2.STL for the cablechain mount. This one has, like the bottom piece, complete support for the bolts.

A redesigned header for the FT5. Push once to the tip of your hotend to the back/front to see what I mean with rigidity.
Extra support for the bolts, extra ribs on front- and backside, higher bottom- and top part give extra rigidity to the header. Absolutely no play in Y-direction anymore.
The top part has the nylocks integrated. Nylocks fit quite tight (you don't want to loose them when everything is mounted) : use a bolt to pull them completely into their seat. (see pictures)
Bottom part has an integrated support for mounting a partcooler. If you have a Titan/Volcano you could use the design from the pictures
Bolts to fix top part on slider are M3/12mm

Mounting is quite straightforward.

Tip : Use 3d-Tool to have a detailed look on this thing

Printer:

FT5

Rafts:

No

Resolution:

0,4

Infill:

60%

Notes:

Printed all in ABS (0,6mm nozzle, 0,4mm layer)
Support needed for bottompart

comments.text: Is this adaptable for the E3D aero Titan ?
comments.author: Bohn1

comments.text:
No ... That's why I designed one for the Aero.
The issue is that the distance between extruder and nozzle is much shorter because the cooler is now integrated in the extruder housing.
Distance between bottom extruder to top of hotend is something like 10mm where this is more like 45mm with the standard cooler mounted.

title: RC Speed Tank
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Scroll down for the english version

Dieser "Speed Tank" schafft mit den Bauteilen die ich nutze ca. 25km/h und das auch Haltbar.
Ich habe ihn bewusst einfach konstruiert damit bald sehr viele von dem Guten durch die gegen fahren :-D
Bei Fragen schreibt mich einfach an und ich werde die Beschreibung natürlich auch ergänzen.

  • Was wird zusätzlich benötigt?

2x 1:10er Combo (60A ESC & 540 35T Motor) http://www.ebay.de/itm/282209095251?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

2x Motorritzel (Modul 1 11 Zähne) http://www.ebay.de/itm/Ansmann-125000800-Motorritzel-11Z-Modul-1-Neuware-Ovp-/310343310087?hash=item4841e71b07:m:mcJ51CPKY4yPDTk5k0B9YTw

2x Adapter Ritzel M1 für 3.175mm Welle http://cs-shop.de/Stahl-Ritzel-Adapter-von-5mm-R-auf-317mm-R

  • Kugellager:

8x22x7mm 608 12x http://www.ebay.de/itm/Kugellager-608-699-2RS-oder-ZZ-Miniaturkugellager-/261604722227?var=&hash=item3ce8db4633:m:ml9uHfw6EXoYNAzL75XQY2A

4x13x5mm 624 12x http://www.ebay.de/itm/Kugellager-624-ZZ-4x13x5-mm-/371744555811?hash=item568db3c323:g:qagAAOSw8gVYAhpA

  • Lipo´s:

2x 3x 2200mAh https://www.amazon.de/Brainergy-Lipo-2200mAh-11-1V-T-Plug/dp/B00JI9JIOS

  • Schrauben:

M4x15mm 8x
M4x60mm 12x
M3x20mm 4x
M3x10mm 4x
M3x45mm 84x

  • Muttern:

M4 20x
M3 88x

Bei der Steuerung werden einfach die beiden Kanäle der Funke gemischt was mit jeder Stick Funke geht bzw auch mit einigen Pistolenfunken.

  • Welche Teile werden wie oft benötigt?

Antriebsrad: 2x
Basisplatte 1x
Front Bumper 1x
hintere Abdeckung 1x
Kettenglied 84x
Laufrolle Kettenspannung 2x
Laufrolle 8x
Seitenteil gespiegelt 1x
Seitenteil 1x
Versteifung gespiegelt 1x
Versteifung 1x

  • Montage:

Es wird alles geschraubt und nichts geklebt. Zudem ist das Fahrzeug komplett Modular aufgebaut für eine einfache Montage/Reparatur

Ich habe alle aufnahmen für Muttern so gefertigt das man diese im heißen Zustand einpressen kann damit diese von alleine halten. Das erleichtert die Montage erheblich.

Die Lagersitze habe ich mit Absicht etwas größer gemacht damit man die Lager gut einpressen kann. Dies ist natürlich auch abhängig von den Druckereinstellungen.

Die 42 Kettenglieder werden mit den M3x45mm verbunden und diese dann mit Muttern gesichert die auch mit Schraubensicherung oder Sekundenkleber gesichert werden.

Das Teil "Laufrolle Kettenspannung" dient, wie es der Name schon sagt zum spannen der Kette. Diese wird als vorderste Laufrolle montiert da diese eine andere Größe hat.

  • Support:

Es wird nur bei den Teilen "Laufrolle" Laufrolle Kettenspannung" "Antriebsrad und "Basisplatte" Support benötigt.

  • Druckeinstellungen:

Geschwindigkeit: 60mm/s

Infill: 20-50% ("Versteifung" & "Seitenteil" mehr nutzen)

Outlines: ich selbst habe bei den meisten Teilen fünf genutzt, vor allem beim Antriebsrad wegen der Verzahnung

alle Teile sind so ausgerichtet wie ich sie auch gedruckt habe

Druckzeit: ca. 90h

Material: PLA/PETG

Drucker: Druckbett von 200mmx200mm wird benötigt

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=z7oRk-XY7QM

in english

This "speed tank" creates with the components which I use approximately 25km / h and also the durable.
I have deliberately simply designed it so that soon a lot of the good will be driven by the :-D
If you have any questions feel free to contact me.

-------------------------------------------------- As shown in Fig.

  • What else is required?

2x 1: 10 combo (60A ESC & 540 35T engine) http://www.ebay.de/itm/282209095251?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

2x Motorritzel (Module 1 11 teeth) http://www.ebay.de/itm/Ansmann-125000800-Motorritzel-11Z-Modul-1-Neuware-Ovp-/310343310087?hash=item4841e71b07:m:mcJ51CPKY4yPDTk5k0B9YTw

2x adapter pinion M1 for 3.175mm shaft http://cs-shop.de/Stahl-Ritzel-Adapter-von-5mm-R-auf-317mm-R

  • Ball-bearing:

8x22x7mm 608 12x http://www.ebay.de/itm/Kugellager-608-699-2RS-orden-ZZ-Miniature Ball Bearing-/261604722227?var=&hash=item3ce8db4633:m:ml9uHfw6EXoYNAzL75XQY2A

4x13x5mm 624 12x http://www.ebay.de/itm/Kugellager-624-ZZ-4x13x5-mm-/371744555811?hash=item568db3c323:g:qagAAOSw8gVYAhpA

  • Lipo's:

2x 3x 2200mAh https://www.amazon.com/Brainergy-Lipo-2200mAh-11-1V-T-Plug/dp/B00JI9JIOS

  • Screws:

M4x15mm 8x
M4x60mm 12x
M3x20mm 4x
M3x10mm 4x
M3x45mm 84x

  • Nuts:

M4 20x
M3 88x

In the control simply the two channels of the spark are mixed which goes with each stick spark or with some gun sparks.

-------------------------------------------------- As shown in Fig.

  • Which parts are required as often?

Drive wheel: 2x
Basic plate 1x
Front Bumper 1x
Rear cover 1x
Chain link 84x
Caster chain tensioning 2x
Caster 8x
Side part mirrored 1x
Side section 1x
Stiffening mirrored 1x
Stiffening 1x

-------------------------------------------------- As shown in Fig.

  • Assembly:

Everything is screwed and nothing sticked. In addition, the vehicle is completely modular for easy assembly / repair

I have made all recordings for nuts so that they can be pressed into the hot state to keep them by themselves. This makes installation much easier.

I have intentionally made the camp seats slightly larger so that you can press the bearings well. This is, of course, also dependent on the printer settings.

The 42 chain links are connected to the M3x45mm and these are then secured with nuts, which can also be secured with a screw anchor or seconds glue.

The part "caster chain tension" serves as the name implies to tension the chain. This is mounted as the foremost caster since it has a different size.

  • Support:

It is only necessary with the parts "Caster" Caster chain tension "" Drive wheel and "baseplate" support.

comments.text: Not sure. I programmed my Taranis to do what I want and threw any standards for functions out the window for this model. Taranis is mode 2, but using the right stick for forward/reverse/left/right. So on the transmitter am using Ele control for throttle and Ail control for left/right. These signals are mixed in the transmitter (not quite right, reverse steering is backwards, need to fix), and am driving output 1 on the receiver for the left motor ESC and output 2 on the receiver for the right motor. Am using the BEC on the left motor ESC to power the receiver and have the red wire from the right motor ESC removed and isolated so only on BEC is powering the receiver.

title: Remixed Prusa I3 MK2 tool holder

description.text:
a nice little tool holder that conveniently allows you to access to the 4 hexes in the original design as well as 3 SD cards, needle nose pliers, a rat tail file, tweezers, and a .4 cleaning bit.
i printed it with the original prusa white that came with my machine with an infill of 20% its plenty strong for its purpose. I modified the moldle so now it will not interefere with the X axis belt idler nut. if there is anisue wit fitting let me know i had to fille a little to make it fit but i moded it in tinker cad a little so hopefully it will work corectly now.
P.s. sorry about my messy desk Lol

Original Prusa I3 MK2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20%

title: Effecteur Magnetic + Sonde bed auto leveling intégrée / Effector

description.text:
Videos

Principe / Principle : https://youtu.be/iCEmxZ5T0OA
Impression / Print : https://youtu.be/ikwoGAey3fY
Assemblage / Assembly : https://youtu.be/SkY21pOv6xk

Instructions en Français (English below)

Présentation

Voici mon second effecteur magnétique, entraxe 45mm, avec une sonde de plateau intégrée. Je l'ai conçu de telle sorte que la hotend soit la sonde et qu'elle puisse sonder tous les plateaux, quel qu'en soit la matière ou le revêtement.

Les chariots d'entre-axe 45mm associés à cet effecteur se trouvent ici : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2438667

L'effecteur est composé de deux pièces :

  • Un corps principal auquel sont reliés les bras
  • Une mâchoire qui tient la hotend.

Le principe est très simple : Ces deux pièces peuvent coulisser l'une par rapport à l'autre uniquement sur l'axe Z. Entre les deux sont disposés des micros-switchs qui permettent de détecter lorsque les deux pièces s'écartent l'une de l'autre. Ainsi, lorsque l'effecteur descend et que la hotend rentre en contact avec le plateau, la mâchoire qui tient la hotend ne descend plus, mais l'effecteur lui continu a descendre. Les deux parties s'écartent, ce qui actionne les boutons poussoirs.

Cette solution a l'avantage d'être très bon marché, très précise, passive et de fonctionner sur n'importe quel support ou revêtement. Au niveau du firmware, il n'y a qu'un décalage en Z à gérer. Il correspond à l'écartement des deux pièces nécessaire pour déclencher la sonde, plus le dégagement de la buse par rapport au plateau (l'épaisseur d'une feuille de papier normalement), soit au total 0,2mm dans mon cas

#define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0.2 // Z offset: -below +above [the nozzle]

L’assemblage de l'ensemble prend environ une demi-heure.
Conception réalisée avec : Autodesk Fusion 360
Toutes les pièces sont conçues pour être imprimées sans support matériel.

Pièces à imprimer
  • Le corps principal
  • La mâchoire en deux parties
Quincaillerie
  • 2 vis M3x12
  • 5 vis M3x20
  • 3 ressorts 3.45 - 4.8 mm 8mm
  • 3 rondelles M3
  • 6 aimants néodyme fraisés D12 d4 e4.75
  • 2 micro switch 6x6x4.3
  • 50cm de fil AWG30
  • 4cm de gaine thermorétractable 1mm
  • Colle cyanoacrylate (Super Glue)
Matériel
  • Paire de ciseaux
  • Fer à souder + fil d'étain
  • Multimètre

Assemblage de l'effecteur (voir la vidéo d'assemblage)

  • Nettoyer la pièce et les trous
  • Vérifier que les logements des aimants et des microswitchs sont exempts de coulures qui pourraient les empêcher de se mettre en place.
  • Souder les câbles des interrupteurs (branchement en série), il est préférable d’effectuer cette opération avant que les poussoirs ne soient collés, sinon il est difficile de positionner les fils, le fer est attiré par les aimants et sa chaleur fait fondre l’effecteur
  • Coller les deux interrupteurs
  • Coller les fils sous l’effecteur
  • Placer les fils au plus près du col, ils ne devront pas gêner le mouvement de vas et vient de la HotEnd dans l’effecteur
  • Vérifier au Multimètre le bon fonctionnement des interrupteurs
  • Coller les six aimants : encoller les trous deux à deux, placez-y les aimants, retourner l’effecteur sur un plan et appuyer pour assurer une bonne adhésion.

Assemblage de la mâchoire (voir la vidéo d'assemblage)

  • Présentez les deux mâchoires face à face et faire prendre les vis de 5 mm.
  • Passez la HotEnd dans le trou de l’effecteur
  • Écartez les mâchoires et passez la HotEnd dans le trou des mâchoires
  • Alignez le passage de câble des mâchoires et de l’effecteur.
  • Placez du Scotch bleu sur les deux aimants coté vis afin de ne pas les abîmer avec le tourne vis
  • Vissez les mâchoires, elles ne se touchent pas et doivent rester parallèles.
  • Vérifiez que les trois centreurs de l’effecteur sont bien en place dans les trois renfoncements des mâchoires.
  • Placez les trois tendeurs : rondelle + ressort +vis, et vissez-les jusqu'à ce que le ressort ne bouge plus librement. Inutile de serrer plus.
  • Faites naviguer les mâchoires pour qu’elles soient bien en place.
  • Vérifiez que vos ressorts sont toujours légèrement en tension, sinon revissez ceux qui le nécessitent. Il faut essayer d’avoir la même tension de ressort sur les trois tendeurs.
  • Connectez un multimètre sur les fils des la sonde
  • Placez le multimètre en détection de continuité (beep quand on touche les deux fils)
  • Vissez une des deux vis de réglage de butée jusqu’à ce que l’effecteur et la mâchoire s’écartent.
  • Faites de même avec la seconde vis jusqu’à faire sonner le multimètre
  • Dévissez doucement une première vis jusqu’à ce que le beep s’arrête
  • Revissez légèrement cette première vis jusqu’à faire sonner à nouveau le multimètre
  • Dévissez doucement la seconde vis jusqu’à ce que le beep s’arrête
  • Revissez légèrement cette seconde vis jusqu’à faire sonner à nouveau le multimètre
  • Vissez ces deux vis d’un quart de tour supplémentaire
    En tenant l’effecteur, appuyez la tête d’impression sur un plan, le beep doit s’arrêter. Relâchez la pression et le beep doit reprendre. La pression à exercer ne doit pas être importante, et le beep doit systématiquement reprendre de manière franche (pas de grésillement ou de bip qui s'arrête et reprend). Si c’est bien le cas, votre sonde est prête ! Si ce n’est pas le cas, vérifiez :
    • le positionnement des mâchoires par rapport à l’effecteur
    • la tension des suspensions
    • le point de bascule de chaque microswitch

Configuration Marlin Firmware 1.1.0-RC6

Cette configuration est celle de ma machine qui est équipée d'une carte Arduino MEGA + RAMPS 1.4, d'un écran + lecteur SD.

Configuration.h

Parce que les micro-contacts sont normalement maintenus en position fermée
const bool Z_MIN_PROBE_ENDSTOP_INVERTING = false;


#define AUTO_BED_LEVELING_FEATURE // Active la fonction de Bed auto leveling
#define DEBUG_LEVELING_FEATURE // active le mode debug pour la calibration
#define DELTA_PROBABLE_RADIUS (DELTA_PRINTABLE_RADIUS - 10) // Je détermine le rayon de la surface sondée égale au rayon de la surface d’impression moins 10mm
#define AUTO_BED_LEVELING_GRID_POINTS 5 //Nombre de points de la grille (doit être supérieur ou égale à 5)


Il n’y a pas de distance a paramétrer entre la buse et le palpeur puisque la buse est le palpeur !
#define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0 // X offset: -left +right [of the nozzle]
#define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0 // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]
j’indique cependant un décalage de hauteur entre le plateau et la buse qui sera égale a la distance parcourue par l’effecteur pour actionner le micro switch + la distance a laquelle je décale la buse pour imprimer la première couche.
#define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0.2 // Z offset: -below +above [the nozzle]


#define XY_TRAVEL_SPEED 4000 // vitesse de déplacement de l’effecteur entre chaque sondage, en mm/min.
#define Z_RAISE_BEFORE_PROBING 30 // Hauteur en mm de l’effecteur avant de se déplacer vers le premier point de sondage
#define Z_RAISE_BETWEEN_PROBINGS 5 // Hauteur en mm de l’effecteur lors des déplacements entre les points de sondages
#define Z_RAISE_AFTER_PROBING 30 // Hauteur en mm de l’effecteur après le dernier point de sondage


Il faut désactiver cette fonction lorsqu’on utilise un capteur pour Z_MAX et un autre capteur pour Z_MIN, ce qui est mon cas puisque le micro switch n’est utilisé QUE pour le Z_MIN. Le Z_MAX est donné par les fins de courses de chaque colonne.
// #define Z_SAFE_HOMING <br> Cette fonction doit en revanche être activée #define Z_MIN_PROBE_ENDSTOP``

pins_RAMPS_13.h

Dans Marlin Firmware , la broche 32 est par défaut configurée pour y brancher la sonde de plateau. La borne 18 est quant à elle attribuée au capteur Z_MINI.
Dans la mesure ou je n’utilise pas de Z_MINI, et que la borne 32 est déjà utilisée par l’afficheur LCD, je réattribue la broche 18 au contact du palpeur en intervertissant les valeurs suivantes :

#define Z_MIN_PIN 18 → #define Z_MIN_PIN 32
#define Z_MIN_PROBE_PIN 32 → #define Z_MIN_PROBE_PIN 18

Compilez et téléversez le firmware.
Pour vérifier que tout fonctionne, utilisez la commande m119 et vérifiez que l’état de vos fins de courses est correct :

Si l’imprimante est en position HOME, vous devez obtenir ce résultat :
x_max: TRIGGED
y_max: TRIGGED
z_max: TRIGGED
z_probe: open

Si l’imprimante n’est pas en position HOME, vous devez obtenir ce résultat :
x_max: open
y_max: open
z_max: open
z_probe: open

Lorsque vous soulevez votre HotEnd par rapport à l'effecteur, vous devez voir changer l'état de la sonde z :
z_probe: TRIGGED

Autres conseils

Lorsque vous palpez votre plateau, pensez au préalable à faire chauffer votre HotEnd à 170°C environ. En effet, il n'est pas rare qu'un petit bout de filament sorte de la buse. Pour que la mesure soit correcte, il faut qu'il s'écrase lorsque la buse palpe le plateau.
Par précaution, pensez également à désactiver la sonde (M121) une fois l'auto bed leveling terminé, car si la sonde se déclenche pendant une impression, l'imprimante considère que la tête à touché sa position Z limite et stop le travail en cours. Ce problème est apparu sur la version 1.1.0-RC6 de Marlin, peut-être sera-t-il corrigé dans les versions futures...

pour exemple, voici mon script de Start g-code (j'utilise Slic3r) :

M106 S128 ; Allume le ventilateur à 50% de sa puissance
M104 S170 ; Positionne la température cible de l'extruder à 170°
G28 ; home
G1 X0 Y0 Z30 F6000 ; Descente de la tête
M109 S170 ; attend que la HotEnd atteigne 170 °C
G92 E0 ; initialise la position de l'extruder
G1 F9000 E-1 ; rétracte 1 mm
G92 E0 ; initialise la position de l'extruder
G29 v4 ; Bed auto levelling
M121 ; désactive la sonde de plateau
G1 X0 Y-100 Z30 F6000 ; Positionne la tête sur l'avant
M109 S[first_layer_temperature] ; attends que la HotEnd soit à température
G92 E0 ; initialise la position de l'extruder
G1 F100 E20 ; extrude 15 mm
G92 E0 ; initialise la position de l'extruder
G1 F9000 E-2 ; rétracte 2mm
G92 E0 ; initialise la position de l'extruder
G1 X0 Y0 Z30 F6000 ; Cente HotEnd

Mise à jour du 10/07/2017 :
  • Ajout d'une variante de l'effecteur pour des magnets de diamètre 10mm
Mise à jour du 04/10/2017 :
  • Modif plateforme pour un meilleur centrage des microswitchs
  • Modif mâchoires pour en augmenter la solidité

===========================================================================

English

entre-axe

Presentation

Here is my second magnetic effector, 45mm spacing, with a built-in bed levelling probe. I designed it so that the hotend is the probe, and it can probe all beds, regardless of material or coating.

The carriage with 45mm between-axle associated with the effector can be found here: https: // www. Thingiverse. com / Thing: 2438667

The principle is very simple: The effector is composed of two parts:

  • A main body to which the arms are connected
  • A jaw holding the hotend.

Both pieces can slide one relative to each other only along the Z axis. Between them are arranged two micro switches that detect when the two parts move away from each other. Thus, when the effector sinks and the hotend comes into contact with the bed, the jaw holding the hotend no longer get down, but the effector itself continuous go down. Both sides move away, which is detected by the push buttons.

This solution has the advantage of being very cheap, very precise, passive and operating on any support or coating. Concerning the firmware, only the Z offset have to be set. It corresponds to the spacing of the two pieces necessary to trigger the probe, plus release of the nozzle from the bed (normally the thickness of a sheet of paper), 0.2 mm in total in my case.

The assembly takes about half an hour.
Designed with Autodesk Fusion 360
All parts are designed to be printed without material supports

Parts to print
  • the main body
  • the jaw in two pieces
Quincaillerie
  • 2 screws M3x12
  • 5 screw M3x20
  • 3 Springs 3. 45 - 4. 8 mm 8mm
  • 3 washers M3
  • 6 magnet neodymium milled D12 d4 e4. 75
  • 2 micro switch 6 x 6 x 4. 3
  • 50cm AWG30 copper wire
  • 4cm heat shrink sleeve 1mm
  • Cyanoacrylate glue (Super Glue)
Material
  • Pair of scissors
  • Soldering iron + tin wire
  • Multimeter

Assembling the Effector (see the Assembly video)

  • Clean the part and the holes
  • Check that housing magnets and micro switches are free from drips that might prevent them from being placed in position.
  • Weld the micro-switch cables (serial connection), it is preferable to carry out this operation before the pushers are glued, otherwise it is difficult to position the wires, the iron is attracted by the magnets and its heat melts the Effector
  • Glue the two switches
  • Glue the wires under the effector
  • Place the wires closest to the neck, they must not interfere with the translation movement of the HotEnd into the effector
  • With the multimeter, check for correct operation of the switches
  • Glue the six magnets: glue the holes two by two, place the magnets in them, turn the effector on a plane and press to ensure a good adhesion.

Assemblage of the jaw (see the Assembly video)

  • Present both jaws face to face and do take the screws of 5 mm.
  • Pass HotEnd through the hole of the effector
  • spread the jaws and pass the HotEnd through the hole of the jaws
  • Align the passage of cable of the jaws and the Effector.
  • Place blue tape on the two magnets side screws in order not to damage them with the screw driver
  • Screw the jaws, they must not touch and must remain parallel.
  • Check that the three centring of the Effector are in place in the three recesses of the jaws.
  • Place three turnbuckles: washer + spring + screw, and screw them up until the spring no longer moves freely. Needless to tighten more.
  • Make navigate the jaws to keep them in place.
  • Check that your springs are still slightly in tension, if not tighten those who require it. Try to have the same spring tension on the three tensioners.
  • connect multimeter on the wires probe
  • put the multimeter in continuity detection (beep when you touch the two wires)
  • Screw one of the two adjusting screws until the effector and the jaw move away.
  • Do the same with the second screw until the multimeter beeps.
  • gently unscrew until the beep stops
  • Slightly tighten again this first screw until the multimeter sounds again.
  • gently unscrew the second screw until the beep stops
  • Screw the second screw slightly again until the multimeter is ringing again
  • Screw these two screws an extra quarter turn
    By holding the effector, press the HotEnd on a plane, the beep should stop. Release pressure and the beep should resume. The back pressure must not be important, and the beep must systematically resume clearly (no sizzle or beep that stops and resumes). If this is the case, your probe is ready! If this is not the case, check
  • the position of the jaws with respect to the effector
  • the tension of the suspensions
  • the tipping point of each micro-switch

Configuration Marlin Firmware 1.1.0-RC6

Cette configuration est celle de ma machine qui est équipée d'une carte Arduino MEGA + RAMPS 1.4, d'un écran + lecteur SD.

Configuration.h

Because the micro-switches is normally held in the closed position by a screw
const bool Z_MIN_PROBE_ENDSTOP_INVERTING = false; // set to true to invert the logic of the endstop.


#define AUTO_BED_LEVELING_FEATURE // Delete the comment to enable (remove // at the start of the line)
#define DEBUG_LEVELING_FEATURE // Activates debug mode for calibration


#define DELTA_PROBEABLE_RADIUS (DELTA_PRINTABLE_RADIUS - 10) // I determine the radius of the probe surface equal to the radius of the print surface minus 10mm
#define AUTO_BED_LEVELING_GRID_POINTS 5 // Number of points in the grid (must be greater than or equal to 5)


// There is no distance to be set between nozzle and the probe as the nozzle is the probe!
#define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0 // X offset: -left +right [of the nozzle]
#define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0 // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]
Height offset between the plate and the nozzle will be equal to the distance travelled by the effector to actuate the micro switch + the distance at which I shift the nozzle to print the first layer.
#define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0.2 // Z offset: -below +above [the nozzle]


#define XY_TRAVEL_SPEED 4000 // X and Y axis travel speed between probes, in mm/min.
#define Z_RAISE_BEFORE_PROBING 30 // How much the Z axis will be raised before travelling to the first probing point.
#define Z_RAISE_BETWEEN_PROBINGS 5 // How much the Z axis will be raised when travelling from between next probing points
#define Z_RAISE_AFTER_PROBING 30 // How much the Z axis will be raised after the last probing point.
It is necessary to disable this function when using a sensor for Z_MAX and another sensor for Z_MIN, which is my case since the micro switch is used ONLY for the Z_MIN. The Z_MAX is given by the end of each column.
// #define Z_SAFE_HOMING


On the other hand, this function must be activated
#define Z_MIN_PROBE_ENDSTOP

pins_RAMPS_13.h

by default in Marlin Firmware, pin 32 is configured to connect the bed auto levelling probe and pin 18 is assigned to the Z_MINI sensor.
Since I do not use Z_MINI, and pin 32 is already used by the LCD, I reassign pin 18 to the bed probe by switching the following values:

#define Z_MIN_PIN 18 → #define Z_MIN_PIN 32
#define Z_MIN_PROBE_PIN 32 → #define Z_MIN_PROBE_PIN 18

Compile and upload the firmware.
To verify that everything works, use the m119 command and verify that the status of your limit switches are correct:
If the printer is in the HOME position, you must achieve this result:
X_max: TRIGGED
Y_max: TRIGGED
Z_max: TRIGGED
Z_probe: open

If the printer is not in the HOME position, you must obtain this result:
X_max: open
Y_max: open
Z_max: open
Z_probe: open

When you move your HotEnd away from the effector, you must change the probe status z:
Z_Probe: TRIGGER

More tips

Before you perform an auto bed levelling, think to warm your HotEnd to about 170 ° C. Indeed, it is not uncommon for a small piece of filament to come out of the nozzle. For the measurement to be correct, it must be flattened when the nozzle probe the bed.
As a precaution, disable the probe (M121) once the auto levelling is finished, because if the sensor is triggered during printing, the printer assumes that the nozzle has touched its Z limits position and stops the current job . This problem has appeared on the 1.1.0-RC6 Marlin version, perhaps it will be corrected in the future...

For example, here is my Start g-code script (I use Slic3r):

M106 S128; Turns on the fan at 50% power.
M104 S170; Position the target temperature to extrude to 170 °
G28; Home
G1 X0 Y0 Z30 F6000; Descent of the head
M109 S170; Waits for HotEnd to reach 170 ° C
G92 E0; Initialises the position of the extruder
G1 F9000 E-1; Retract 1 mm
G92 E0; Initialises the position of the extruder
G29 v4; Auto Bed levelling
M121; Disables the bed probe
G1 X0 Y-100 Z30 F6000; Position the head on the front
M109 S [first_layer_temperature]; Waits for HotEnd to be at temperature
G92 E0; Initialises the position of the extruder
G1 F100 E20; Extruder 15 mm
G92 E0; Initialises the position of the extruder
G1 F9000 E-2; Retract 2mm
G92 E0; Initialises the position of the extruder
G1 X0 Y0 Z30 F6000; Cente HotEnd

Update of 07/10/2017
  • Add of variant of the effector for magnets of diameter 10mm
Update of 04/10/2017 :
  • Update plateforme for a best microswitchs positioning
  • Update jaw to increase strength.

comments.text:
hi can you upload the files so i can put the numbres in the pices
thanks
comments.author: thegundamaster

comments.text:
i already tried that myself, but most slicer programs cannot render the gcode correctly, and putting numbers on it will corrupt it..
that is why did not add the numbers, but said that writing on it was the best solution for the current version.
(i also checked for bad sectors in the print using x-ray from cura, and there where 0 parts that where corrupt)
printing such parts will also decrease the quality a lot due numbered parts needing a different position for printing
comments.author: thegundamaster

author: fprocyon

title: Wip: Tiny articulated bot added supports

description.text:
Shira made this very cute robot model. My son of 2.5 years loves it. But I had some trouble printing it. The head moved during the print and the hands fell out afterwards.
I added some extra supports to the head. Now you can print it as large as you want. ;-)
Also the hand joints were slightly enlarged so they will not fall out.

It is a quick and dirty fix with several meshes intersecting so I used Cura slicer with expert setting > fix horrible. > combine everything [Type-A]
Use a knife or cutters to cut the 4 small bars in the gap of torso and neck. Then snap the original supports by force to release the head.

comments.text: It's a great remix as the original has a lobotomy when I printed it! I've made 3 of these and all were perfect. Just take your time separating the 4 small holds on the head etc and it'll be fine. Well done!
comments.author: Robertcu2018

description.text: This is a simple Domino set I created in AutoDesk 123D Design as an exercise in learning tools and familiarizing myself with the features. This set goes up to a double-six. The dots are hollowed spheres, and all corners are rounded off.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20

Notes:

Using S3D to slice, printing Hatchbox PLA at 200C, 50mm/s

Used AutoDesk123D design to create a box of domino dimensions, then rounded the vertical corners using the fillet tool. Proceeded to round the top and bottom faces using the fillet tool to give the block a nice rounded shape. I made a smaller box to serve as the center divider and rounded the bottom off using the fillet tool as well, then arranged it with the main block, then performed a subtract of it from the main body. The dots were formed with spheres of 2mm diameter, sunk 1mm into the surface in their respective positions, then subtracted from the main structure.

title: FlashForge Bed Leveling Nut - for M3 Nuts

description.text:
I did not like how my wingnuts would move/vibrate slightly over time and later cause minor warps.

These bed level knobs take M3 'nylon locking' nuts, combined with the large surface area on the top I have found them to stay stable.

I printed them with scaling on my dreamer set to 26.24mm on the X and Y to account for the slight difference in my machines.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.07mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

PETG on a FlashForge Dreamer (please note, the model above would not let me select the dreamer)
Bed Temp on borosilcate glass at 52 and 245 on the extruder - Maker Geeks series PETG
Insert M3 nut and push it fully to the top of the knob. Run a bolt through prior to installing on the printer to clear out the printed threads and help level the nut.

title: Geetech i3 Pro B mount for e3D customizable extruder

description.text:
This is a bracket designed to fit https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1383913 to a stock X carriage on a Geeetech i3 Pro B with a metal X carriage. It may also work on other Geeetech printers, if it works for you, please leave a comment to let others know!

Full OpenSCAD source is included with this thing, but it is a bit hacky.

This bracket was designed to be affixed with M3x8mm screws, but M3x10mm screws will probably also work.

Printer:

Geeetech Prusia i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

35%

Notes:

I printed this in PETG because of its higher glass point. PLA may work, but I have not tested it. I recommend enabling supports everywhere and printing this with the back of the mounting plate on the bed.

I used the following settings for the hotend mount (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1383913) and it works fine for my printer. These are the default settings at the time of this writing. These settings should place the end of the e3D v6 about 10mm below the X carriage. You may need to use a slightly longer Z end stop screw. 

dual = false;          
mirrored = 0;  
prometheus = false;   
width = 42.5;
depth = 30;   
height = 51;
height_m = 20;  
cover_d = 16;
holes_top1 = 35; 
holes_spacing1 = 30;     
holes_top2 = 23;    
holes_spacing2 = 23;
holes_top3 = holes_top2 + 23;        
holes_spacing3 = 23;
filament_d = 1.75;
gear_od = 9;
gear_ed = 6.75; 
gear_groove_width = 3.5;

This bracket was created in OpenSCAD. The mounting holes and cutouts were measured from the X carriage.

description.text:
This simple tripod phone adapter will have you shooting better stills and videos on your phone in no time! Fits most smartphones on the market right now.

All you need is a small SAE nut with the following dimensions to fit the screw on your tripod:
7/32'' high
7/16'' wide (plane face to plane face)
20 step

The small hole in the stem of the top part which aligns with the slit in the stem of the bottom part is made to insert a small bit of 14ga wire to prevent the parts from falling apart when the bolt is not tightened. Not necessary but useful.

Ideally the big parts should be printed with the stems being horizontal, this will provide optimal strenght for the parts.

Enjoy!

description.text:
I present yet another printed box! This one is nice because it prints reliably and is strong and large. It doesn't use printed hinges because I wanted the lid & body to be individually replaceable in case on half fails. Metal hinges such as the nails I use also make the joints much stronger and much more reliable to print, preventing an 8 hour print from failing just because a print setting was off.

I have found lever C to work best as a latch, but B may work better for you if you want a looser fit.

I designed this box specifically for electronic components storage. It's sized so that a bag from Mouser Electronics will fit snugly, thus allowing you to store components in their original ESD packages. For loose components or anything else that's small I have found 3x4" plastic bags (readily available on Amazon) to work well for managing them.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

250 Microns

Infill:

20%
minimalist

title: gear for LEGO DUPLO train motor
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Often cause damage of trains Lego hollow - split gear on the motor shaft.
This is not a problem, if you have a 3D printer.

Especially for repair of my locomotive I modeled this gear.

Gear must be worn tight on the motor shaft.
To put the gear on the shaft, I wasted edge of the inner hole of printed gear a little by using stationery knife and push it onto the shaft with force.

Printer:

DIY prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

100

Notes:

nozzle: 0,3 mm
layer height: 0.15 mm
speed: 20 mm/sec

extrusion multiplier 0.9

author: gtbuzz

title: Epoxy, Painting, or XTC-3D Part Coating Surface

description.text:
I'm starting to try out coating my prints with XTC-3D for smoothing, and couldn't find anything to set the parts on while they dried. So I made this array of cones as a surface where you can place a part on, epoxy it, and (hopefully) easily remove it.

It's designed such that you can print multiple of them and piece them together to create whatever size surface is needed for your work.

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

author: ellie_l

description.text:
Picatinny Rail for standard Ruger 10/22, uses all four mounting holes. May fit other models, I don't know. Arc on bottom is a bit too pronounced to sit flat on the receiver, I will update model when I have a chance.

Free to print, share, make for friends...just don't be a douche and try and make money off these.

UPDATED - second version with clearer numbers as some printers struggle with the messy numbers.

description.text: Print with glow in the dark filament, add some double sticky tape to the back side and stick on your walls and ceiling for a spaced out look!

During the assembly process of my XMachines Lorei kit, I noticed that if the mounting screws of the LCD screen were tightened to much it would deform the LCD control board. I know that this is a really simple item but, thought I would throw this up here just in case someone else didn't feel like drawing it up.

Printer:

Rafts:

No

No

40%

title: The Periodic Table of chess set #Chess

description.text:
This part was made with Tinkercad. Edit the part online at: https://tinkercad.com/things/hooLZxdcdNI
This is my second build in tinker cad and i must say it is a really nice program for beginners. I have done some modeling in Blender, and Sketchup whitch have much more capabilities than tinkercad, but tinkercad's click and drag system makes everything really simple. this is my second build, took me about 1hr. my first print i am saving to upload until later. this is just to show what tinkercad can and can't do.
i don't own a 3d printer at this point (the reason i am entering this contest) but from what i understand you should use the support structure function because of the overhangs, and just print

description.text:
Need a organizing shelf for all those loose screwdrivers, paint brushes and the like for your bench. Here it is! This design uses Customizer to adjust to your specific needs for each of the three shelves.

Measure diameter of your screwdriver to the just above the grip and shank. Add that to the shelf hole diameter. Measure from that point on the handle to the end of the blade to add 5mm and this will be the height of that shelf. Repeat for the next two shelves.

Let me know what you think or if you run into issues.

UPDATE - I had to beef it up a little. My 8 year old went through these brackets in a week. Here is the beefier bracket - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2044383

Designed using SketchUp 2017. Plastic brackets for my kids clothing drawers keep breaking. Took the old bracket, measured, and designed this. The abs brackets printed work but some have broken when I apply too much torque on the screw.

This is an enclosure which I have developed for the rumba motherboard. It will mount to the 20 x 40 extruded aluminum tubing for the delta printer which I am in the process of creating.

The enclosure has been created in four sections, which are intended to be bolted together using 3mm bolts and nuts. There are two 40 x 40 x 20mm fans which mount internally and connect to a duct. The air is directed to the heat sinks of the stepper motor drivers and exhaust out the back.

The display case shown has been created from the following: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1814828

description.text:
Additional base stand for Anycubic Kossel Linear (and possibly for similar Kossel printers with 20mm extrusions) which raises the whole printer by 52mm, to provide clearance for a 50mm tall power supply (or additional space for the electronics).

There are two 4mm mounting holes to attach it to the printer (with M4x10 screws and nuts), and a rebate with three 3mm holes on two sides designed for side panels up to 4mm thick to be fitted. It also has an opening to allow the end-stop wires to be run down the central hole in the tower extrusions.

There's also a 3.5mm through hole which I tapped with an M4 thread, so that a base panel could be attached with three countersunk M4 screws.

If the machine has 240mm extrusions, the side panels would need to be 240x52mm. There are three 3mm mounting holes either side, so each panel could be mounted with either 2 or 4 screws.

I've included an optional captive nut plate which can be used to hold two M3 nuts, which then allows the side panels to be removed and replaced at any time, without needing to upend the machine and remove the base. To attach this plate, I used a countersunk screw and nut through the central hole, and the two outer holes are then used to mount the panel.

For the side panels, I also made this fan cover:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2039193

cilynx has also designed some printable side panels which can be customised:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2577313

Printer:

Anycubic Kossel Linear

No

No

20%

comments.text: The triangular base was made from 9mm MDF board (although 6mm would also be fine). I put the printer on the MDF and drew round it with a pencil, then used a jigsaw to cut the outline. Then I just lightly sanded it and sprayed with matt black paint. The base panel is secured with 3x M4 countersunk screws, which go straight up into the printed base stands (I tapped the holes with an M4 tap).
comments.author: Jstokes

comments.author: peaberry

comments.text: What you see at the corners is some black PU foam for vibration damping (not essential). In my case I also fitted some large 30mm diameter rubber feet under the base board (again, to reduce vibration/noise). The fans are also attached to the side panels with silicone washers. I also made this fan cover: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2039193

title: dropper bottle paint holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a dropper bottle holder for miniature acrylic paints. I made it specifically to fit in an ArtBin and accept Army Painter bottles. They are 24mm in diameter which should also accept Vallejo and other 18ml paint bottles.

It is broken into 2 bottom plates and 3 upper plates to fit on smaller print beds. The top and bottom should snal together but might require a little sanding depending on your printer tolerances. Gluing is optional but I would recommend it to make it stronger.

There are three small protrusions designed into each to hole providing just enough resistance to hold the bottles in even if held upside-down.

It is sized to fit in a 12" Art Bin Quick View carrying case. There is a little room leftover for a couple miniature stands and a few brushes. https://www.amazon.com/ArtBin-12-Inch-Carrying-Container-6977AB/dp/B001ELDERU/

author: Kd5jbk

description.text: The Shinkiro mech from the anime Code Geass. Unlike the previous two mech models I made; this one does not use ball and socket joints. I designed new joints that uses a piece of 1.75mm filament to keep it together at the pivot (labeled Test Joint V 3 in the stls) and use flexible filament to print out the portion that the pivot swivels on (labeled Test Joint V 3.1). The Arms, Legs, Thighs, Shoulders, Hands and Toes all need to be printed twice, and the wings four times. The stl Test Joint V 3.1 and the neck need to be printed in a flexible filament, everything else can be printed in PLA or ABS. The stl Test Joint V 3.1 needs to be printed 28 times, the stl Test Joint v 3 will need to be printed 9 times and the stl Test Joint V 3.2 will need to be printed twice.

comments.text: Awesome model!
comments.author: ligglo

comments.text: Most of the joints will use the file Test Joint 3, and Test Joint 3.1. Test Joint 3.1 is supposed to be printed in a flexible filament so that the pegs on Test Joint 3 can be pressed into the holes; i think i included that in the description, but i might as reiterate just in case. Anyway all the square slots on the various parts are supposed to be the places where Test Joint 3.1 are inserted into. Each of the Shinkiro's toes need one Test Joint 3.1 and they are assembled just by super-gluing those sections together side by side and then onto the end of the leg. Test Joint 3.2 is used for the upper arm to connect the shoulder to the forearm, and the square section on Test Joint 3.2 is supposed to have a Test Joint 3.1 inserted into it so it may be attached to the joint that will be the elbow. I also printed the neck in a flexible filament so the head could be snapped on more easily.
comments.author: ligglo

comments.text: Thanks for the fast reply!
comments.author: liemprefon

comments.text: To fix the issue of the toes, try to scale down Test Joint 3.1, The measurements for the diameter of the holes from the CAD model of Test Joint 3.1 are 2.00mm and 2.50mm, and the measurement of diameter the end of the Toes is 1.50mm which is supposed to go into the smaller 2.00mm hole on Test Joint 3.1. I suggest making a few test prints scaled down incrementally by 5 or 10% to to see which scale fits the best before printing the other 7 in that same scale. I printed mine without scaling it but that is because my printer isn't the most accurate thing so that 0.25mm clearance all the way around the ball worked for allowing it to be pressed into the joint and retain enough friction to hold its position.

title: 144:1 Cycloidal Reducer for FRC PM15R-25F-1001 Motor

description.text:
This version of cycloidal gear box is customized for FRC Legal Part PM15R-25F-1001.
You just add 1X 608z 8mm id skate bearing, 1X F608zz 8mm id bearing, and 1XM8 Hex cap bolt to complete the project.
Suggest use metal ecc shaft to connect the motor and ecc_gear.

The design is inspired from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1278875 and other university project.

In some case, FRC team are looking for high reduction ratio, and compact designed gearboxes. The available options from Andy Mark or Vex are good but not best suit for the FRC project.
Also, existing models for GrabCAD or other source are not fit for FRC legal motors.
Therefore, we modified and designed our own gear box.
By share it to the world, hope we can help out someone with similar requirements.

Benefits of cycloidal gearboxes
• Zero or very-low backlash stays relatively constant during life of the application
• Rolling instead of sliding contact
• Low wear
• Shock-load capacity
• Torsional stiffness
• Flat, pancake design
• Ratios exceeding 144:1 in a compact size
• Quiet operation

description.text:
Simple Rack for Dollar Store Rectangular Containers. (10 Pack)

Uses x2 Neodymium Magnets to hold it onto any metal surface.

Magnets are 6.35mm x.6.35mm x 25.42mm N42 Strength.
1/4" x 1/4" x 1"
https://www.kjmagnetics.com/proddetail.asp?prod=B44X0

Can hold about 4-5 lbs. (Approx)

Enjoy!

Printer:

FolgerTech Prusa i3 Aluminum 2020

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.12mm - .20mm Layers .4MM nozzle

Infill:

60%

Notes:

Use a 5 line Brim, remove only the outer brim after printing.

Chill the Magnets in the Freezer to contract the metal just a bit.

Once Freezing cold, they should slot into the cut outs on the rack, or gently tap in.

Then using no glue, they will be secured in once they warm back to room temp.

The brim being left on the back, prevents the magnets from shattering when they tap hard onto the surface they adhere to.

The fitment is VERY tight. The Freezer trick was REQUIRED to get mine into the part without breaking the plastic cut outs.

Suggest putting the magnets in BEFORE the part has time to cool completely.

title: Extruder Extra Sleeve Holder/Bracket for Anet A8

description.text:
Mithilfe dieser Halterung wird das Gewicht des Kabelstrangs gestützt. Damit erreicht man einen stabileren Halt, wodurch er nicht nach unten fällt/knickt. Der Strang verläuft somit sauber nach oben und läuft einwandfrei beim Druck an jede Position mit. Ohne Halterung hat man das Problem - dass je nach Gewicht - der schwere Kabelstrang gerne nach unten absackt. Diese Halterung sorgt für Stabilität und kann mit wenigen Handgriffen montiert werden. Das Loch ist mit 15mm groß genug, um allerlei Kabel auffassen zu können, sogar mit Autolevel-Sensor.

EINFACHE INSTALLATION:

1.) Entferne am oberen Halter lrechts die beiden Standard-Schrauben (M4x8).
2.) Mit zwei neuen M4x10 oder M4x12 Schrauben kann der Sleeve Holder nun befestigt werden.

--

This bracket supports the weight of cable sleeves. This provides more stable hold, which does not bend downwards. The cord runs smoothly in any position during printing. Without a bracket you have the problem - depending on the weight - the heavy cable harness likes to drop downwards. This bracket provides stability and can be mounted with a few hand movements. The hole with 15mm is large enough to cover all sorts of cables, even with an auto-level sensor.

EASY INSTALLATION:

1.) Just remove two default screws (M4x8) on the right side over extruder at the holder.
2.) For installation the new Sleeve Holder you have only to use two new M4x10 or M4x12 screws.

Anet A8

50%

description.text: This is a set of bone folders, one with sharp edges and one with slightly rounded over edges. When I lost my previous bone folder in a move, I didn't feel the need to buy a new one for 10 bucks, and besides, 40 minutes to print both is better than 2 days to wait for one in the post (I still love you Amazon Prime). For those of you who are unfamiliar, a bone folder is simply a bone or plastic tool designed to allow one to make sharp folds and creases in paper while minimizing finger fatigue, often used in book binding and origami due to the large amount of paper folding in both of these crafts. In addition to .stl files for both folders, the download includes the Autodesk Inventor .ipt files needed to edit the models should anyone choose to do so (I welcome you to make them suite your needs!).

A 3D model showing the position of the major stars in the Big Dipper asterism (constellation). By looking through the ring, the viewer sees the stars as they are from earth.

This helps demonstrate that constellations aren't flat, but rather coincidental 3D arrays of stars.

Note that the Big Dipper is one of the best constellations (asterisms) to do this for, with the furthest star being only 2.5 times further than the closest. in some constellations, the ratio is in the hundreds.

This is an arrow for a crossbow created by CyberCyclist:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:964321

I've printed it using my MakerGear M2 + Simplify3D. You definitely need to use a raft because it is long and thin, which means it can easily fall over if you are not careful. It is roughly the same width as a straw but much shorter to make it easier to print. I've added small wings to try and make it more stable during flight. My testing suggests that it does indeed improve its range somewhat.

author: go0se

title: Figurine Joint
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a joint I made for use in making 3d-printed action figures and models. Originally I made a different joint, that was much larger than the this one, but I wanted to make smaller figures so I ended up experimenting with the tolerences that my printrbot play can work with, and was about to make a smaller joint in a size I am happy with. So, I will be using these to make modular action figure parts instead of my previous Modular Action Figure Joint. The hinge portion of the joint in Test_Joint_V3 is held together using any 1.75mm plastic filament, in my case I use PLA and occasionally ABS. The parts Test_Joint_V3.1 are printed in a flexible material so that the pegs on Test_Joint_V3 can be pressed into the smaller hole. The length of the joint should allow for the larger bit of the peg to clear the smaller diameter hole and rest on the should between the larger hole and the smaller one. I sometimes sand the larger bit of the peg to give it a taper or point so it can more easily pressed through the hole.

comments.text: How do you connect them with in the hole?  some sort of spike? I dont quite get it from the model.
comments.author: Adrian1986li

comments.text: Thank you, your comment made me realize I did not put in the description how I connected the joints, and I will edit that. For the holes in Test_Joint_V3 &V3.2 they are connect with a piece or 1.75mm plastic filament, I used PLA. For the rectangular base that It connects to, to swivel, I printed Test_Joint_V3.1 in a flexible material and sanded down the two pegs on either end of Test_Joint_V3 (and/or 3.2) to a point or to put a taper onto it so that it can easily be pressed into the smaller hole on Test_Joint_V3.1.

title: Sky Drone Pro V2 Spare leg skid for Menkind Red5

description.text:
This is a spare leg for the Sky Drone Pro V2 sold by Red5 and Menkind.
Unfortunately both have been out of stock of spare legs and after a heavy landing we needed a replacement leg for the Sky Drone Pro V2. Although the injection molded parts would have been preferable I sketched up this replacement, that honors the original's height.

It is hollow and thin to keep the weight down to minimum. The fitting to the body has two circles and a screw through middle of one of them.

Printed in grey here to make it visible for camera, black or strong colours look great on the drone.

11 Jan 2017 - Added V5 that uses even less plastic and is even lighter. It has a curve that is to try and keep out of the camera's view. Print the leg in left and right pairs, mounting so as to provide the widest view for the camera between them. This version is flat on one side so it can be printed with less support.

Measuring 1.5" x 1.5" x 0.25" when unfolded, this hinge lays flush when folded backwards or forwards, and when laid flat. The holes are 0.14" in diameter to clear the major diameter of a size 6 wood screw.

I designed this to be used with a folding table so that the hinge could be inlaid on the top face of the table, and the table could be folded upwards while remaining flush. Other hinges on the market have circular cross-section pins that would have required an additional groove be cut out of the wood, and both planes of the table rotating about the same offset axis posed clearance problems.

author: Gamethyme

print_settings.Notes:: For printing lithophanes i print them vertically so the X-Y axes generate the gray scale (best resolution). The curved mode gives best base support for vertical printing.

description.text:
This lithophane base is designed to fit GE incandescent nightlights (#52194) and support lithophanes made using "Image to Lithophane" (http://3dp.rocks/lithophane/) generated using the outer curve mode.

The idea is that you glue your printed lithophane onto the curved base and the C-shaped adaptor fits snug in the groove at the base of the GE nightlight. Its an easy to make nightlight lithophane.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Printrbot Simple Metal

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Its only 4 mm tall so its a quick print.

For printing lithophanes i print them vertically so the X-Y axes generate the gray scale (best resolution). The curved mode gives best base support for vertical printing.
To attach the lithophane (printed separately) to the base i used #4 Acrylic solvent cement. Superglue would probably work too.
designed in 123D Design using a micrometer to measure the GE nightlight.

title: 1:24 German Tiger Battle Tank Driving Sprockets

description.text:
My grandson received a 1:24 scale German Tiger Tank for Christmas but the driving wheels soon failed. They had a hex extrusion which the driving axles fitted into but were chewed out and made circular after a shot time. There was not enough support materail surrounding the extrusions.

I used Autodesk Fusion 360 to learn how to draw gears and after many adjustments, have a set of replacements printed in PLA using a Prusa i3 Mk2.

Printer:

Prusa i3 Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

40%

Cleanup

Because of the overhang on this design, I had to clean up beneath the top sprocket with a sharp knife.

Autodesk Fusion 360

I measured the existing sprockets with a vernier caliper and then drew this in Fusion 360. Had to modify a few measurements to make the teeth align with the tank's tracks.

I am a novice when it comes to 3D drawing but learned a lot putting this together.

comments.text: there are two problems with the tank your grandson has first the sprocket second the track comes too tight so i suggest adding one of the replacement track pieces to both sides
comments.author: tanklover

description.text:
This is a Recycling logo. I designed this to put on a bin in my house so people could identify it without asking. There are little grooves at the corners of the arrows to replicate the fold on the original recycling logo.
It is a single piece and ts 2mm tall and about 80mm across at the widest point.
I printed in ABS and I attached it to the bin using a few drops of acetone.

Printer:

RepRap Prusa I3 - Folgertech

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

This is a Kit that turns a C-clamp into a soft-jawed vice that features a slot made for holding PCB's. It fits all needs for a soft jawed vice, as well as being able to stand completely on its own. After printing it is incredibly simple to put together assembly and disassembly takes less then a minute. It is a great light weight kit that turns a C-clamp into a portable desktop vice, everyone loves multipurpose.

Everything you need for this print is contained in one .zip file for easy access as well as compact storage. You need to print out two legs.

LINKS:

The C-clamp as seen in the picture
https://goo.gl/4zFqvq

MatterHacker's MatterController
http://www.mattercontrol.com/

Go check out the amazing products over at poindexters closet: https://poindexterscloset.com/

If you liked this you might also like my other projects on my page.
http://www.thingiverse.com/Outlandish_Gamer/about

Would you like to be up to date on my new designs? Link to my Twitter
https://twitter.com/?lang=en

Do you want to see how I design things? Youtube:
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCB1IT-J0rLiaPwLNTUFh9Lg

Happy Printing!

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Any

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I highly recommend using Matterhackers mattercontrol 1.6 if you are controlling your 3D printer from your computer via USB connection. This program is free and easy to use and produces very high quality prints. I switched from Cura because I was having issues with the prints, However with this program I have had no problems what-so-ever even on longer prints. I also suggest using Elmer's glue stick or other glue sticks on top of tape on your printing bed; This helps a lot with bed adhesion.

Disclaimer:
I am not in any way affiliated with MatterHackers. They have a great software that I use on a daily basis. Link in the summery.

author: sirscuba

description.text:
This is a version of @rssalerno's SDD adapter, cut down to a smaller size that fits on the (120x120) bed of the Monoprice Select Mini 3D printer. It leaves just 8 vertical mounting screws, which was just what I needed to put a SSD in the 3.5" drive trays of my PC case.

Thanks to @wholesalepcllc for prompting me to post my remix.

(yeah. I know. it's a laptop HDD in the photo, not an SSD. It still works)

I clipped the original file using a small openscad script.

module original() { import("SSD_Bracket_v3.3.stl", convexity=10); }

intersection()
{
    original();
    translate([8,-1,-1])
    #cube([86,110,6]);
}

If you have different needs (for instance, would like to preserve the horizontal 3.5" mounting screws), this is a great time to learn enough OpenSCAD do to it---just modify the numbers in cube([]) to include more or less of the original, and the numbers in translate([]) to move the corner of the preserved portion. You'll feel like a super hero!

Thank You!
9/1/14
I own a MakerBot Thing-o-Matic but wanted a second 3D printer that worked the same way. Along came the discovery of MakerSlide so using MakerBot Gen4 Electronics/MakerBot parts on MakerSlide/Misumi and 80/20 extrusions, I present to you this 3D printer variant.
I have a working version but still trying to figure out how to mount the electronics. This is my second attempt with revised parts which I have posted.
Update 03/29/12 - Added more SKP files.

Still trying to figure out where I should mount the MakerBot Gen4 electronics. Missing right now are
  • Safety Cutoff switch mount
  • Gen4 Electronic Mount
    Parts were printed with PLA.
    The extruder mount is designed to hold the standard MK7 mounting plate.
    Hot Bed Plate mount uses from 4 to 8 magnets to secure/attach to the carriage plate. Magnets can be sourced from SparkFun ( http://www.sparkfun.com/products/8643 )
    Thumbwheels origin: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18823
    I have an general sense of where I will place that BIG ATX PSU. It will most likely installed to the right. I have a video printing the prototype mount: http://vimeo.com/38744027 The SKP file and STL files for the PSU holder are now available.
    Something wacky is going on with my ReplicatorG 29r2 where parts printed are mirrored. Since most parts are symmetrical it didn't matter but seems to affect:
    -MK7 Mount
    -Endstop Front
    Yet another issue to try and understand. Did a little searching in the MakerBot operator with little success.
    More info and instructions coming. Since it is taking me forever to figure out where to mount the electronics strategically, I am posting what I can. Parts were designed in Google SketchUp 8. Files will be uploaded eventually.
    To hold the extrusions together and other parts of the printer, I use the following screws and washer:
    • Black Oxide Alloy Steel Low Head Socket Head Cap Screw, Hex Socket Drive, M5-0.80, 10 mm Length
    • Black Oxide 12.9 Alloy Steel Button Head Socket Cap Screw, Hex Socket Drive, M5-0.80, 10 mm Length
    • Metric Black Oxide 12.9 Alloy Steel Socket Head Cap Screw, Hex Socket Drive,
      --M5-0.80, 30 mm Length
      --M5-0.80, 40 mm Length
    • Size #10 Flat Washers
      Below are sources of inspiration for some of the parts I created in SketchUp.
      Idea for Belt Clamp origin: http://www.buildlog.net/forum/viewtopic.php?f=33&t=1127
      Idea for Hot Bed Plate Mount origin: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13497
      Idea for Carriage Plate origin: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12504
