comments.author: philtrum

comments.text: Hi Phil.  Thanks for the question.  Short answer is no.  I don't have any pictures to post.  However, if you try looking for "Makerbot endstop" images for Thing-o-Matic in your favorite search engine you'll get an idea that it sits on top of this mount.  Basically this mount was designed so that the carriage plate hits the trigger switch of the endstop when properly oriented.  Hope this helps!
comments.author: philtrum

comments.text: I am do not understand the belt clamp stl...  how does the belts fit in and how can you adjust them..  I looked in the instruction but he link did not look like this belt clamp...  so I having a problem moving my belts and working with them on this system..  thank you .. great system..
comments.author: rkomar

comments.text: You would do your best to get the belt tension tight when installing into the clamp and then pull the stepper motor or pulley back to increase tension.  The way the belt locks is to create a loop near the end of each side of the belt that goes around their respective circle.  The belt is held in place via the slot when the teeth of the belt are interlocked.  The concept is to have the belt teeth pull in different direction to stay in place.  Hope this helps!
comments.author: rkomar

comments.text: Can you advise where you can find the copper nutball for Z.  I am looking all over for these.
comments.author: rkomar

comments.text: The "copper nutball for Z" that you mention is something that comes with the Threaded Rod NEMA 17 Stepper Motor that was sold at http://store.makerbot.com/parts-accessories/thing-o-matic-repair-parts-accessories.htmlhttp://store.makerbot.com/part.... It has been "Out of stock" for a while now. I don't know any other place that would sell the nut itself. You could always purchase the threaded rod and nut together and attach it to a stepper motor but having the thread rod integrated with stepper motor is best in my opinion. Hope this helps!
comments.author: rkomar

comments.text: A small note: you can probably get away with using only 4 total wheels on the outside (or maybe inside) for the Z-axis as long as they are decently snug. I know those wheels are pricey.  ;)
comments.author: MakerCubed

comments.text: Haha, this is one of the reasons I wanted to post early (awesome suggestion).  I didn't plan for the Eccentric Spacer to be on the outside but I think with what you suggested, I could get them "decently snug" by adjusting the four outside vwheels and remove the inner four.  It would definitely reduce the overall weight of the X-Axis too.  =-X
comments.author: MakerCubed

comments.text: Here are my findings:  Having four Eccentric Spacers was a nightmare to adjust.  What I ended up doing was flipping the left side carriage plate so that I could use the non-moving vwheels and just adjust the right side vwheels.  This was done with the Z-Nut mount loose so I could make the final adjustments on the Z-Axis afterwards.
comments.author: makerwill

comments.text: Thanks.  As it is, it will be the same print size as the Thing-O-Matic.  There is room to add a larger surface and limited by the MakerSlide lengths, belt length and the size of printing surface.  I have tried attaching a 9"x9" acrylic sheet with Kapton tape to print PLA with great success.  This was done by securing it to the top of the Aluminum Build Surface plate as I was curious of the potential print area.

description.text:
Turbine utilising a combination of direct impact and cross-flow propulsion.

This is based on the Ugrinsky turbine design with a simpler geometric construction composed of only circles.

These models spin well from breath power, but would probably need to be scaled up for use to generate useful amounts of electricity.

The most recent update of the model includes the following features:

  • 3 pass-through channels, and 3 collecting blades
  • screw mounting holes for easier printing
  • screw mounting holes for stacking multiple turbines to each other (offset)
  • holes for putting in 4x6x8mm magnets
  • hole/gap for a 608 skate bearing

title: Micro 115mm FPV Quadcopter, HS1177, Piko BLX 3" quad

description.text:
Frame inspired by the Micro 110mm design made by t4b_ http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1783281 Huge thanks for motivating me to build a cute little micro quad!! ;)

Made to support: PIKO BLX Micro Flight Controller, Furious FrSky Micro Rx, HS1177, 1306/1407 motors.

This frame is made with a few features specially tailored for 3d printing. (100% infill)

  • Stiffness added by using ridges along the arms.
  • Sunken screws to prevent LiPo damage.
  • Wider Battery Strap holes fitting perfectly with those cute and thin lipo straps...
    http://rotorgeeks.com/index.php?route=product/product&path=72&product_id=572

Custom Mount to support HS1177 Cam using the Armattan Uni POD. http://www.armattanquads.com/armattan-uni-pod/ (Printed in TPU or similar material like cheetah)

12/01/2017 - Added Antenna Holder for TX and VTX.
15/01/2017 - Replaced XT60 by XT30, saving a few grams to get the quad weight bellow 250g.
09/09/2017 - Added camera protection model..

That little quad fly's very well and can take quite a beating! But, it is starting to show some stress on the ABS around the standoff... A new and improved, micro swift, 4 inch version is coming up.... ;)

Hardware
M3 Screws (5mm & 10mm) and Standoff (22mm & 30mm)

OpenScad library with modules which can generate spirals.

***See note at bottom regarding STL before printing! I was intrigued by all of the curvilinear forms I've seen on thingiverse, and wanted to create some of my own, and more importantly, do it without having to generate lists of points and triangles. This openscad library accomplishes those goals by hulling together a bunch of simple sphere shapes.
Included modules are:
spiralSimple
spiralCone,
spiralEllipse
spiralMulti
spiralMultiCone
spiralMultiEllipse
and some others Further instructions for use are included in the comments section at the top of the spiral.scad script. Additional notes for use:
I acknowledge that this is by no means the most computationally efficient means to generate spirals. In fact, the attached object is composed of lots of medium resolution spiralMultiCone ojects and the program would sometimes crash before finishing rendering.
If this happens to you, there's a way around it. Create separate scad files with each unit, e.g. a scad file that just has a single spiralMulti, render than object and "export to stl" Do this for all of the high render time objects and then combine in a master scad file using the import("partFileName.stl"); function. Each of these can be translated, rotated, etc. as desired and it allows for the construction of highly detailed objects without throwing errors or having obscenely long single run times. Addenda:
  • I switched to using a ubuntu system with the linux distribution of openScad on the same laptop. The program no longer crashes, but build times can still be extremely long.
  • Warning to Plastic Extrusion printers: The demonstrative STL file attached contains wide bridges, and it is not recommended for printing with extrusion printers.

description.text:
Customized 144:1 Cycloidal Reducer for FRC Legal Part AM-0912.

This design provides high ratio reduction, and light weight. The high speed motor has 1/8 in shaft. The reducer transmit the power into usable 8mm shaft for many robotic projects.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/jemYXLJKyEo

This project is inspired by:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1278875

Design to use 2 stages cycloidal plate 12 teeth and 12 teeth, yield 144:1 high reduction. It is useful to show the design concept and benefits of cycloidal gearboxes:
• Zero or very-low backlash stays relatively constant during life of the application
• Rolling instead of sliding contact
• Low wear
• Shock-load capacity
• Torsional stiffness
• Flat, pancake design
• Ratios exceeding 200:1 in a compact size
• Quiet operation

add following materials:
1 608z bearing
1 f608z bearing
1 M8 hex cap bolt

comments.text: Hello, I would really appreciate you marking your design as a remix of mine: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1278875/ Many of your parts are obvious 11/8 scale-ups to fit a 608 bearing - especially the inner rotor, which matches mine polygon-for-polygon.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Do you find yourself constantly eating food where you need a fork to indulge but don't have one on hand or they are all dirty and you don't feel like doing dishes? Fear no more and eat always and anywhere with this retractable fork iPhone 4 case.

There are 3 separate pieces to this "thing". To assemble, place your fork in your track and acetone or glue the "Fork Track" to the "Case Body", make sure it is well aligned. Now you have a Fork Case!  
I used a Makerbot Replicator to print all of these pieces and Makerware to write each piece's G-code. For the iphone case body printing on Makerware's standard setting works fine. For the "Fork Button" piece change the printing quality to "high" quality and for the "Fork Track" change the infill to "linear".  
Have fun!

title: MP Select Mini Universal Bearing for stock spool holder

description.text:
The Mini's stock spool holder is hard edged and jerks the filament when it's rolling. This creates excess vibration and resistance on the extruder gear, as well as being kind of noisy. This little 30-minute print fixes it in the simplest way possible.

Just print the bearings upright with support touching the bed in the filament of your choice. drop them on the stock spool holder, and slide them under each end of your spools center hub. Taa-Daaah! A smoothly rolling filament feeding machine!

These work with most standard sized .5kilo-1kilo spools. Haven't tested them on smaller spools, but they should work fine as long as the spool hub diameter is over 50mm

(Don't be afraid to sand a little if you print at a larger layer height and the spool doesn't roll smooth. You might need to knock down the layer lines to get it really rolling.)

Update: I taped off the bearings and coated the inside where it touches the spool arm with a coat of flexible rubber sealer. Bearings stay in place much better.

This is my version of the Beast Grip. I saw a couple of versions on here, but they either used threaded rods, or were just not what I was looking for.

This one makes use of 3D printed parts, aluminium linkages meant for RC rock crawlers, and a fairly cheap clip on 2x lens. My specific version uses the following:

2 x Aluminium Linkage Rod, M3 x 6mm x 95mm (vertical rods that hold the lens carrier)
2 x Aluminium Linkage Rod, M3 x 6mm x 105mm (horizontal rods that hold the phone clamp)
1 x Aukey 2x Telephoto clip on lens.

The rods I used had slightly different OD's. The 95mm length rod was 6.01mm, while the 105mm length rod was 5.84mm. The parts are designed with those in mind and may require some drilling / sanding to fit your parts.

The lens carrier is designed for a specific clip in lens (see my make), but you could easily design a different lens carrier. It needs to have 6mm holes for a sliding fit, 80mm center to center. With that info, you could design anything you want.

Additionally, you could use longer horizontal rods to be more flexible on the fitment of different phones.

This design, as is, holds my OnePlus One, which is a 5.5" phone, with room for a larger phone potentially, as well as a smaller one. It should hold an iphone or iphone plus just fine.

This is the first version, I am still revising the phone clamp to something spring loaded, as well as making the lens carrier more universal; maybe clamp something to clamp in a threaded fitting. I worked with what I have.

The whole thing should be printable without supports. Just be smart with how you lay it out on the build platform.

description.text:
here it is my lightsaber is a public file i ask you do not sell it please and thank you you are more than welcome to use it for yourself... now thats out of the way.
parts:
1" pex tube from menards (clearishwhite) mine was a 5 foot straight stick (cut to 40") 6$

flashlight menards 20$ or eBay 8$

flash gel eBay different options 8$ for pack of 20 colors

and of course 3d print the 2 files i printed in one piece but i have a big printer you may have to break it down. the hilt prints upside down because there is a ledge inside. this way you don't need support. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2024985

the pex tube will have black lettering on it just take paper towel and rub it off it should rub off with a little effort

use small zip ties and a little superglue to keep the flashlight in it extended position. (smallest focus point)

once the parts are printed there is some post processing to keep it strong tolerances are tight. clean up the plug and get it to fit inside of the hilt, then clean up the inside of the plug and get the flashlight botton end to fit through it.

next is the hard part you have to get the flashlight to tightly fit into the hilt basically get the inside smooth i used sandpaper on a dowel rod. the light will not fit from sanding. i had to lightly grind the flashlight to get that perfect fit. (reason for this is so its as tight as possible so it doesn't move around)

next sand the inside of the hilt where the blade goes until it fits

put the flashlight in the bottom and put the plug on the flashlight will be tight in place. now push the blade down to the flashlight so they touch. then proceed to drilling holes in next part

i drilled holes to fit 5mm screws. one for the light(drilled through hilt and plug at same time without flashlight in) and 2 for the blade through the hilt and the blade.

install your 2 screws for the blade

now take the light out and cover the end with a flash gel of choice and reinsert into hilt. put on the plug and put in your set screw i used 10mm for this part.

and there ya go a cheap lightsaber that looks awesome

i want to see them when your done building them

and remember may the force be with you :)

title: Mavic Pro Rear Landing Extension with Lighting Mount

description.text:
This is a remix of the rear landing extension from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1977003, thanks @filmscum. It is still a work in progress so expect changes to come.

You will also need the front legs from the thing this is remixed from, I have added extra tabs that will allow you to mount some lights (like the Strobon strobe lights or other small battery operated light you may want to add) on the rear of the Mavic for visibility without having to mark up the Mavic itself. There are tabs to a mount light that faces to the rear as well as tabs to mount lights facing to each side. You can also mount some white LED lights on the underside of the tabs to aid the vision system when landing at night. The piece can still be taken off and stored if lights or extensions are not necessary.

Here is a YouTube video testing my first print with the lights zip-tied to the tabs where they will eventually be hot-glued in place. https://youtu.be/LdIxl0FUL3M

FlashForge Creator Pro

Yes

20%

This print will require some supports, it is not a lot but if you want the item to look nice it is recommended to sand the spots where the supports are. For a really nice look you can also give it an acetone bath which will virtually remove all lines and make the part very smooth.

Made from scratch in 123D Design using reference pictures from the movie and from StefanFX's pictures of the canisters he made. I haven't had a chance to print anything yet so I'd appreciate any feedback from anyone printing one of these. I've also included my in progress 123DX file if you want to start where I left off. The final height will be around 14 inches, but I've split it up into pieces that should slide easily together, the tallest of which is around 7 inches. I'll post more about printing and some pictures of the final project as I go. Enjoy and happy printing!

Update
I've added files for a new scream meter and scream meter details to eliminate the need to paint the red part of the meter with silver accents. I've also split the middle of the canister into two pieces with a removable brim at the bottom for better bed adhesion.

Update
Just added some pictures of the canister painted and assembled. All that's left is to make the decal that goes around the scream meter and the warning decals for the side. Also, the top comes off for storage, perhaps a swear jar?

Update
Just added the pictures of the final product, special thanks to StefanFX for the files for the decals. For the color decals I used high quality outdoor label paper and for the letters I used Grafix Rub-onz transfer paper. You can find both of those at Hobby Lobby or Wal-Mart.

description.text: This is a replacement camel for the Camel Up board game. You can use this to make replacement pieces. Or, if you use black filament, you can make your own "Camel Up: The Referee Camel" expansion.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Use 100% infill, otherwise the piece will be too light.

I created the outline in Inkscape by first tracing a piece from the game, and then scanning the trace. I then manually created bezier curves to match the outline. A lot of trial-and-error went into fine-tuning the curves so that the printed piece would match official pieces from the game.

I saved the outline to DXF format, and then imported the DXF into Sketchup using the "FreeDXF 16a" extension. I followed the instructions on https://forums.sketchup.com/t/dxf-to-push-pull/15242 to convert the outline into a shape that I can push/pull. I used push/pull to create the 3D object, and then I exported it as an STL.

title: S4 Case with Speaker port to front of the phone

description.text:
I just completed the remix of the Galaxy S4 case by RealAbsurdity.
I want to thank him for providing an amazing base model to work from. It adds a pocket that allows the sound to travel to the front edge of the case rather than through the back. In my search for a case that does this, I haven't found anything that solves this problem. I will add pictures once I print it on my dual replicator in the next couple days. If anyone tests this and has suggestions for changes, please leave a comment and I will gladly make alterations. After my first test print, I will be considering adding additional space to insert small strips of foam pad to further surround and insulate the speaker port from vibrations.
See RealAbsurdity's printing instruction, as I believe they will yield the best results. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:99152/#instructions

author: Matthewflinchbaugh

print_settings.Notes:: Best to print in ABS or other high temp plastics. (I have been using PLA without problems so far)

title: Bolt-On Bowden Mount For a Stock Monoprice Maker Select V2.1, Wanhao Duplicator i3

description.text:
Update 1-11-17 - Push fittings are adding slop. Use compression style fittings, but don't over compress as it will tighten the tubing around the filament.

Update 3-12-17 - I originally designed the extruder mount as an open design. Its been pretty cool for me to watch the filament feed, and easy to clean stringies and such without dismantling the whole thing. And to load filament I was using a pair of mini needle nose pliers from Harbor Freight. After I changed the rolls 10x in a day, I found this too impractical. So good news!! I added in sort of guide rails for quicker filament changes!

Your 3d printer does so much for you! So do it a favor and take a little weight off its shoulders!

I introduce to you, a bolt-on Bowden system I built for my completely (as of now) stock Monoprice Maker Select V2.1 (and this will inherently work for the Wanhao Duplicator I3).

Get rid of that moving mass, lessen your vibration, increase your quality, print faster! 

 Parts and Instructions

Parts List (pretty simple)

Bolts -
M3-0.5x8mm (x2 to attach the motor mount to the Z-frame)
M3-0.5x10mm (x2 to mount the motor to the motor mount)
The original motor mount bolts M3-0.5x(mine were 37mm) can be used. I bought 40mm is what i used. If you want to be safe you can use a 45mm length which will allow room for a nyloc.

I got all the nuts and bolts by walking into Home Depot, in their small bolts bin.

Tubing-
You can use pretty much whatever tubing you want, Seems the 3d community uses 1/8" PTFE, but I didn't have any laying around or wanted to wait for shipping. At work I did have access to 5/32" O.D. Synflex tubing which works great!!
The mount holes are designed to accept 1/8" NPT fittings.
So whatever tubing you decide to use, make sure they have 1/8" pipe threads.
I'm currently using 24" of tubing, 28 might be ideal?

You might have done some Googling by now and asking yourself.
How do I get my hands on some Synflex without buying a 500' roll?

Call or walk into any number of your local heavy duty diesel repair dealerships/ repair shops (Freightliner/Kenworth/Volvo/Peterbuilt). You can buy it by the foot and some shops have multiple colors. They should have both tubing and fittings! make sure you get push fittings. Maybe if you're lucky you will come across some freebee scrap trimmings or clean used pieces! Some parts departments are open 24h, so don't be afraid to call in the middle of the night!

Assembly (a little more complicated but simple)

  1. Print your parts!! lol there is a left and right motor mount for either side of the gantry (note: the left side print will orientate the extruder lever to the back).
    The Extruder mount will swap your fan to the right side. Makes everything nice and centered (but you can mirror this piece if you require a different view). Clean your printed pieces, insert the fitting into the motor mount. Wait to install the extruder mount fitting
    1. Install the motor mount on the 2 existing upper bolt holes. Use two 8mm bolts(any longer and the Z-carriage will contact).
    2. Unclip your extruder motor connector. (take some pics so you know where each wire is connected!!!!!).
    3. Using the eye-side of a needle, insert into the top wire side of the connector to free the lock tab, and pull the wire and needle out at once.
    4. Take a small piece of scotch tape and wrap the wire connectors. Align the wires together and flat keeping the shape of the ribbon, using a small piece of scotch or packing tape (smooth tape) not bulky. This prevent the edges of the connectors catching as you pull them through the cable chain.
    5. Gently pull the extruder motor wire/s back through the chain. Keep the chain straight wherever the taped connectors are as they don't like to bend. Also you only need to pull the wire ribbon it out of the X-axis chain.
    6. Un mount your extruder motor and install to your motor mount with two 10mm bolts.
    7. Select your bolt sizes you plan to use and attach the extruder mount. Place your push fitting over the hole and start to screw it in by hand while looking thru the center of the fitting. Align it so the filament port is at the furthest bottom of the fitting opening or barely visible.
    8. Tubing - Use the corner of a razor blade and taper the inside of one side (like a funnel) and insert that side into the motor mount and the other side into the extruder mount.
    9. Calibrate! Raise your extruder slowly to the top, verify your clearance and you can print the full 180mm. If your bed is leveled on the high end of the z-stop, you will loose clearance.
      Viola!!

Pictures explaining the install are found here

https://www.facebook.com/ModifiedDesigns3D/photos/?tab=album&album_id=1878180105751362

For the most part, this is a finished model. Ill see if I can squeeze in the last few mm for those that have their bed calibrated on the high end. Comment or send a message so I know how much as my printer clears the whole 180mm.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Any

Infill:

Atleast 25%

Notes:

Best to print in ABS or other high temp plastics. (I have been using PLA without problems so far)

title: XYZ Davinci DropIn E3DV6 v2.0 hidden clamp nuts for flush fan shroud

description.text:
Required extra pieces:

2 x 25mm M3 screws
2 x M3 regular nuts (nylons will not fit)
1 x Clamp
1 x Fan Shroud

The fan shroud and clamp can be downloaded from the original designer.

Here: www.thingiverse.com/thing:1328848

Print using supports and abs. I like to use rectilinear and a 0.2mm offset.

You will probably want to redrill the holes with a 3mm bit.

The previous drop in replacement case did not allow for flush mounting of fan shroud without using glue (as noted by its original creator). Also this design allows you to secure the clamp by allowing m3 nuts to be placed in between the fan shroud and the drop in replacement. These m3 nuts allow for secure clamping of the e3d hot end using m3 screws and m3 nuts hidden behind the fan shroud while still allowing for flush mounting of the fan shroud to the drop in case.

print_settings.Notes:: I printed on the Prusa i3 Mk2 itself in Prusa PLA using the standard 0.2mm profile. This part is not anywhere near the hot end so PLA should be fine. You could use ABS or PET if your motors run hot, but mine barely get warm using the "Silent" setting.

title: Prusa i3 Mk2 Strain Relief for X Motor

description.text:
The Prusa i3 Mk2 has very good strain relief on the cables from the extruder motor, and doesn't need any on the cables from the Y and Z axis motors because they don't move. But the X axis motor moves up and down with the Z motion and there is no strain relief where the wires come out of the motor and enter the spiral-wrapped harness. Because of the spiral wrap this is the most flexible point and bends the most. Eventually the wires may fail where they enter the motor.

This small piece solves this problem by immobilising the wiring harness directly below the motor.

It is fixed to the X-axis motor with a single M3 x 8mm machine screw into the unused mounting hole on the front of the motor. It is secured to the spiral-wrapped wiring harness with a single cable tie.

This is a straightforward print, requiring no supports. It is easy to fit, requiring no disassembly of any parts of the printer.

Notes:

I printed on the Prusa i3 Mk2 itself in Prusa PLA using the standard 0.2mm profile. This part is not anywhere near the hot end so PLA should be fine. You could use ABS or PET if your motors run hot, but mine barely get warm using the "Silent" setting.

In the downloads you can find a STEP model which you should be able to import into any CAD software to make this change. If you don't currently have something I would recommend Fusion 360 (it's free) but even TinkerCAD could do this I think. Good luck, and please feel free to post a remix.
